H0.text: Reflecting is what occurs when lenses bend and concentrate light in telescopes used to observe distant objects such as stars.

H1.text: Polarizing is the term that describes what happens when lenses bend and concentrate light in telescopes used to observe distant objects such as stars.

H2.text: Diffracting is the term that best describes what happens when lenses bend and concentrate light in telescopes used to observe distant objects such as stars.

H3.text: Refracting is the term that best describes the process by which lenses bend and concentrate light when telescopes observe distant objects such as stars.

A4.text: The objective in a refracting telescope refracts or bends light.

A5.text: A refracting telescope (also called a refractor) is a type of optical telescope that uses a lens as its objective to form an image (also referred to a dioptric telescope).
